title: How to write email asking someone to do something politely - Quora

It depends on what that something is, but in general, do what you would for any formal email. Start with a basic greeting (e.g. Hello John).Add an opener that leads into your request (e.g. I hope you're semester is going well so far).Make your request (e.g. I was hoping you could read the last email I sent you).Explain how this request will help you and/or them (e.g. If so, you would know that I have invited you to be interviewed for our cultural diversity department, and I would know when to schedule your interview if you choose to participate).Express the gratitude you would have for the request (e.g. Thank you for taking the time to read this email).Close the email (e.g. Best wishes, Jane).

Hi there! Can you please give me a little more detail about your question? Get to the point and don't do so much small talk that you come across as if you're just being nice in order to butter then up. Be genuine. Make sure to be respectful regardless of the answer and make sure you're careful to not come across as pushy or manipulative. Be aware that there is no tone over text so it matters how you word it. Also, depending on what you're asking, there are some situations and questions that you should ask in person. For me, there are just some things I feel is not appropriate to ask over text or via email.

Include “please”, “thank you” for one. You can also say “I appreciate your help on this” or “I’m having a problem with ——— and I hope you can assist me” or anything along those lines. Just keep it simple and don’t lay it on too thick where it sounds insincere in your request. Since I tend to be rather direct (ENTJ) I often write my emails AND then go back and review it and add the “fluff” that others tend to appreciate if they are a different type. So, you might try that and use the suggestions above. After a while it becomes second nature. I hope this helps.

This depends on what you asking for—a favor, date, a loan? If you are merely asking for something relatively small, such as a favor, a ride to the airport, a lunch date, then it’s totally acceptable to ask that in a email. If you are asking for something much larger, say to pay off your student loans—I need to ask you, “Why an email?” The larger the request or “ask”, the less appropriate an email becomes. You need to muster the courage to ask for something big, in person or at least, on the phone—not always easy. But, there are always exceptions, and perhaps communication is difficult, time zones or other obstacles. Then, as a last resort, ask in an email.

It all depends on what you are asking for and the value of the request. I believe that important requests are always accomplished with a face-to-face meeting. However, if you cannot make the request in person, then simply be polite in your email. The problem with email communication is that about 80% of our intent is communicated with body language. In addition, there is a question about the relationship that you have with the person to whom you are making a request. My advise would be to ask in person, prepare your rational for the request, and simply be polite. If you must use email, then read and reread your email to be sure it communicates clearly your request.

Unless you are trying to be cryptic, you have already answered you own questions - ask politely. Since I do not know what you want to ask, it is hard to say anything else. Some things, however, can’t be said politely. For example “Dear friend, would you be so kind as to jump off the nearest bridge? It would be greatly appreciated and I would be in your debt!” Consider this - somethings are better asked in person, so before you email, ask yourself (politely of course) if someone was asking you the same question, would you rather receive it in a email, or in person?

Briefly, and prefacing it with politeness and an understanding of the other person’s circumstances if relevant. Be precise, and not as though you expect to receive what you ask for. If you can state it briefly, a note on what this means to you (without applying pressure). End with a thank you.

My way has always been to ask/ type/ write as if I was talking to that person face-to-face. Keep it polite and keep it clear and basic. I’m “Old School” and always use please and thank you. If it is business, keep it formal. If it is a friend or relative, you can lighten up a bit, but do not overdue it. No 4 letter words or a lot of slang terms!
Do not. Speak to the person you wish to ask a favour. Seeking a favor on email puts it in black and white.

Your level of formality in your email request depends on how familiar your resource/ friend is with you and the dictates of where you work. Requests should be short, sweet, and and free of vulgarity. They can include a brief and honest reason why you need the resource that only they can provide. Hope This helps!
